Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Infrastructural Development and Urban Participatory Governance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Designing and maintaining infrastructures is as much a social problem as a technical one. Understanding the interplay between governance, communication systems, and mechanical infrastructures is a critical part of developing and managing urban spaces. This study, which trains a graduate student in methods of rigorous, empirical data collection and analysis, traces connections between the built environments of roads, the social lives of users, and the processes of negotiation they engage in. By revealing unexpected ways in which infrastructures function, this research will contribute to broader discussions among urban planners, municipal bodies, and other institutions invested in the governance of urban spaces.

Neha Dhole, under the supervision of Dr. Laura Brown of the University of Pittsburgh, will explore the relationship between models of social distance and urban infrastructures in planned landscapes. In many cities, roads and surrounding spaces are used in ways that are rarely recognized by municipal bodies. They are places where people sleep, sell food, park vehicles, post advertisements, and engage in other forms of connection and contestation that shape urban life. This research examines debates among residents, workers, municipal bodies, and other state authorities over the care of roads in New Delhi, India, an appropriate laboratory for asking such questions because of its pilot of a participatory urban development project. The project focuses on one of several neighborhoods planned and built by the Delhi Development Authority to promote secularism and equality among dwellers. Drawing on interviews with residents, street vendors, domestic workers, technical experts, and bureaucrats, along with observation of interactions among them through face-to-face conversations, online exchanges, petitions, and newsletters, the study will examine the link between material infrastructure of roads and conversations, institutions, and forms of sociality. The project will combine analytic models from anthropology, sociolinguistics, and urban planning to better understand the enmeshment of roads and other communication networks. Results will be useful in framing and evaluating participatory governance systems, particularly in thinking through how social media can shape decision-making processes at the local, municipal, and national levels. More broadly, the study will map shifting connections between religion, class, and public spaces in India and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded the study of how roads and related infrastructures are maintained through participatory governance in New Delhi, India. The researcher used multimodal and multi-sited ethnography to reveal when, how, and using which media people align as they make claims to local infrastructures. The study elicited the relationship between scales and forms of transportation infrastructures, and the modes of communication used by neighborhood residents and administrators to maintain them. The study examined talk, writing, images, and other place making practices that occurred in both face-to-face and digitally mediated contexts. Results illustrate that new media does not displace face-to-face interactions, (hand)written petitions, and signed documents when it comes to local governance in Delhi. In fact, these communicative channels are deemed necessary and more persuasive during times of crisis.  

Research was conducted in adjoining neighborhoods that comprised urban villages, 'unauthorized colonies', gated bungalows, and neighborhoods planned by the Delhi Development Authority. Although clusters of these neighborhoods lay in separate administrative districts, they were connected by roads, services, and communicative platforms. Residents negotiated their movements across the porous boundaries to work as daily wage-laborers, to shop for groceries, or walk in the parks. The researcher studied how the material conditions of these interconnecting roads and streets, along with debates on their maintenance, shaped their access for different populations. She paid attention during these interactions to people's co-construction of affiliations to certain regions, classes, castes, genders, age groups, and religions, especially since the neighborhoods historically fell under an area known for the migration and settlement of Muslim, Christian, and Dalit populations. Delhi was an ideal site for this research because of the various levels of administration: neighborhood, municipality, city, and nation. This enabled the researcher to analyze the impact on participation in democratic governance, as social legitimacy of power and secular ideals were bound to multiple groups and institutions. 

To gain an understanding of the everyday life of people in the neighborhoods, the researcher drew on a variety of interviewing methods including: oral histories, cognitive walkthroughs, photo elicitation, and diary studies, as well as participant observation. She participated in neighborhood events, meetings, and Whatsapp groups; volunteered with non-governmental organizations; worked with government web portals and mobile applications to analyze complaints about roads; and observed interactions between those who lived and worked in the localities. She also interviewed residents, neighborhood associations, local politicians, street vendors, shopkeepers, sanitation workers, social workers, local religious leaders, hyperlocal media outlets, municipal councilors and engineers, along with scientists, planners, and architects who design roads. Doing so explained the different (and often contradictory) perspectives on the uses and ownership of infrastructures, and the varied ideas of mobility within neighborhoods. 

The researcher connected face-to-face interactions in neighborhoods with moments when the use of different media and distinct social alignments were highlighted. Key moments included massive protests against a waste incinerator that caused air pollution, and national elections when the state of infrastructures was fiercely contested in local constituencies. Tracing infrastructural issues as they unfolded in campaigns across India's political spectrum further showed the connections between everyday talk about roads and formal political systems. 

The data reveals that road infrastructure is produced and made habitable by networks of humans, animals, computers, phones, and paper, which mediate interactions between streets and governing bodies. Although Whatsapp has a considerable reach among the general public, government employees, and non-governmental organizations, it has not replaced meetings, documents, and signatures needed to manage infrastructures. By bringing together studies of language, communicative infrastructures, and materiality, the research shows how analog media (such as paper documents, newsletters, and signboards) work in dialogue with mobile applications and websites to shape understandings of place and belonging. 

The research also has implications for conceptualizing 'civil society' as it shifts from competitive to collaborative according to postcolonial histories of cultural, political, and physical demarcations. The study addresses what claims on infrastructures as 'public goods' mean when access, ownership, and prospects of land and other built environments are still determined by social differentials.
